repnme.cdata!:
Pakistan - Punjab Education Reform
            Adjustment Credit Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Punjab Education Sector
            Development Policy Credit Project for Pakistan were as
            follows: outcomes were satisfactory, the risk to development
            outcome was moderate, the Bank performance was satisfactory,
            and the Borrower performance was satisfactory. Some lessons
            learned included: Strong political support and government
            ownership is essential for any program to succeed. This
            leads to high level of monitoring and oversight. Continuity
            of the same team over a project, including officials and
            politicians at various tiers helps maintain momentum of
            reforms and enhances the probability of success of a
            program. Success of a program requires a flexible approach
            to implementation with effective monitoring and evaluation
            of the program during the implementation process with the
            help of relevant data and information to identify
            shortcomings and problem issues and be able to rectify them
            during the course of implementation. Strong ongoing
            analytical work helps deepen and refine policies and
            programs. Finally, the success of any education system is
            judged by the quality of its graduates. While quality
            remains the core desired outcome of any education reform
            program, it takes several years to show tangible results.
            Therefore, education reforms require a long term commitment,
            backed by a clear strategy for improving school level
            performance through both quantitative and qualitative inputs.

repnme.cdata!:
Pakistan - Third Punjab Education
            Development Policy Credit

abstracts.cdata!:
This purpose of this proposed third
            development policy credit is to support the Punjab
            Province's three year Education Sector Reform Program
            (PESRP). This proposed credit will complete the series of
            annual programmatic development policy credits (DPC) in
            support of PESRP. Phase II of PESRP is being prepared by the
            Punjab Government, and the Bank has been requested to
            support it through a new series of annual DPCs. Key pillars
            of the PESRP are: (A) public finance reforms to increase
            public spending for education (and other pro-poor services)
            and to ensure fiscal sustainability; (B) reforms that
            strengthen devolution and improve the fiduciary environment
            and governance; and (C) education sector reforms to improve
            quality, access, and sector governance. There has been
            steady progress during the past two years, and the Program
            is showing improvements in enrolment and in reducing the
            gender gap at the primary and middle school levels. The
            proposed third credit will assist the Government in
            completing the agreed reform framework.
